item.title: Nelson Mandela Hospitalized Again for Lung Infection
item.description: The former South African leader Nelson Mandela was in “serious but stable condition,” the government said.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: Nelson Mandela, the former South African president, in 2012.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: June 8
item.description: Europe on U.S. surveillance; the meaning of Taksim Square; business hopes in Myanmar; and tennis showdown in Paris.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: Kitra Cahana for The New York Times

item.title: Former South African Leader Mandela Is Hospitalized
item.description: The office of South Africa’s president says the former leader Nelson Mandela has been taken to a hospital because of a lung infection.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Obama and Xi Tackle Cybersecurity as Talks Begin
item.description: President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China also planned to discuss issues of economics during their talks, and Mr. Obama has been urged to bring up human rights.
item.dc:creator: By JACKIE CALMES and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and President Obama appeared on Friday at Sunnylands, an estate in Rancho Mirage, Calif.

item.title: U.S. Internet Spying Draws Anger, and Envy
item.description: European reaction to reports of American surveillance on the Internet ranged from outrage to muted envy from some in law enforcement.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC PFANNER and JAMES KANTER

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Officials Ban a Far-Right Rally
item.description: The French authorities have banned a far-right youth rally set for Saturday in Toulouse after the killing of a leftist student this past week stirred alarm over violence by ultraright groups.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Bolivia: Suspect Buried Alive by Mob
item.description: Prosecutors said that they had filed murder charges against two men suspected of leading angry townspeople who buried alive a teenager they believed had raped and killed a woman.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Bomber Strikes Iranian Pilgrims
item.description: Suicide attackers on Friday rammed car bombs into a bus carrying Iranian pilgrims and into a police checkpoint west of Baghdad, killing 19 people in all.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Peru: Ex-President Is Denied a Pardon
item.description: President Ollanta Humala said that he would grant a pardon to former President Alberto Fujimori, who is serving a prison sentence for human rights violations and corruption.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Army Officer Killed in Kashmir
item.description: The Indian Army said that one of its officers was killed Friday in an unprovoked firing from across the cease-fire line with Pakistan in disputed Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Arrests in Poultry Factory Fire
item.description: The president of a poultry processing company and its general manager have been arrested in the factory fire that killed at least 120 people and injured at least 77 others this week.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: At Least 47 Die in Bus Fire
item.description: A fire that gutted a commuter bus, killing 47 and injuring dozens in southeastern China, appears to have been deliberately set, state media quoted investigators as saying.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Administration Says Mining of Data Is Crucial to Fight Terror
item.description: The foiling of a 2009 plot to bomb the New York City subway seemed to be the kind of success President Obama was referring to when he defended “modest encroachments on privacy” to protect the country.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT, DAVID E. SANGER and CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: News of U.S. Surveillance Draws Anger Abroad
item.description: Activists and militants expressed outrage over the disclosures about the global scope of American data mining and surveillance of private information conveyed over the Internet.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Katie Orlinsky for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hadi Ghaemi of the International Campaign for Human Rights in Iran.

item.title: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
item.description: President Obama on Friday defended government efforts to gather telephone and Internet data, and sought to reassure Americans that his administration was not listening in on their calls.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: DealBook: France Expands Inquiry Into Tax Evasion at UBS
item.description: UBS, the target of a widening tax-evasion case in France, was placed under formal investigation on suspicion that it illegally helped French citizens to set up secret accounts abroad.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: The Swiss bank UBS in Zurich.

item.title: Protest in Bosnia Over IDs Traps Hundreds in Parliament
item.description: The captives were freed after protesters demonstrated against an impasse over a law on identification documents that had left babies unable to travel abroad or see a doctor.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Bosnian women and their babies were at the forefront of Friday’s protest. A health crisis involving an infant unable to travel because of the ID impasse helped create it.

item.title: Choice for U.N. Post Gets Israeli Vote of Confidence
item.description: Samantha Power, who is facing some resistance from pro-Israel groups, was praised by the Israeli ambassador to Washington.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Samantha Power listened as President Obama announced her as his pick to be the next ambassador to the United Nations.

item.title: Policy ‘Troika’ for Europe Financial Woes at Odds
item.description: Throughout the crisis, chiefs at the European Union and the International Monetary Fund have been part of a policy-making triumvirate that also includes the European Central Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Pierre Mauroy, Former French Socialist Premier, Dies at 84
item.description: As France’s first Socialist prime minister after World War II, Mr. Mauroy pushed through what his party considered to be important reforms.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: François Mitterrand, left, with Pierre Mauroy, in March 1974.

item.title: U.S. Drone Strikes Pakistan as Sharif Names Cabinet
item.description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has often criticized the United States’ use of unmanned aircraft against militants.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Palestinian Farmers in Gaza Buffer Zone Remain Wary
item.description: Farming lags in an area close to the fence separating Gaza and Israel, amid confusion about Israeli restrictions and fears of military incursions.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Palestinian farmer, Ziad Abu Ettewi, at his pepper field near Gaza's eastern border with Israel.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Masters of the Universe Gather in Watford
item.description: More than 100 members of the global elite are meeting through the weekend to discuss the fate of the world. The secretive Bilberberg Group has previously gathered at venues like St. Moritz and Versailles. This year members have chosen an unglamorous commuter town just outside of London.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Protestors watched arrivals at the Bilderberg venue on Thursday.

item.title: Shaping Taksim Square
item.description: The decision by Turkey’s prime minister to clean up Taksim Square has provoked outrage.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Khalid Albaih’s Pen Leaves a Mark Across the Arab World
item.description: By day, Khalid Albaih works in a museum. After hours, he is a cartoonist with an attitude, inspiring discontented youth across the Arab world.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
